question.text: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>2</mn><mo> </mo><mi>mol</mi></math> of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>Hg</mi><mfenced><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi></mfenced></math> is combusted in a fixed volume bomb calorimeter with excess of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math> at <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>298</mn><mo> </mo><mi mathvariant="normal">K</mi></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>1</mn><mo> </mo><mi>atm</mi></math> into <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>HgO</mi><mfenced><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi></mfenced></math>. During the reaction, temperature increases from <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>298</mn><mo>.</mo><mn>0</mn><mo> </mo><mi mathvariant="normal">K</mi></math> to <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>312</mn><mo>.</mo><mn>8</mn><mo> </mo><mi mathvariant="normal">K</mi></math>. If heat capacity of the bomb calorimeter and enthalpy of formation of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>Hg</mi><mfenced><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi></mfenced></math> are <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>20</mn><mo>.</mo><mn>00</mn><mo> </mo><mi>kJ</mi><mo> </mo><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">K</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup></math> and <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>61</mn><mo>.</mo><mn>32</mn><mo> </mo><mi>kJ</mi><mo> </mo><msup><mi>mol</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup></math> at <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>298</mn><mo> </mo><mi mathvariant="normal">K</mi></math>, respectively, the calculated standard molar enthalpy of formation of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>HgO</mi><mfenced><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi></mfenced></math> at <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>298</mn><mo> </mo><mi mathvariant="normal">K</mi></math> is <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi><mo> </mo><msup><mi>kJmol</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup></math>. The value of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mfenced close="|" open="|"><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi></mfenced></math> is___[Given: Gas constant <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi mathvariant="normal">R</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>8</mn><mo>.</mo><mn>3</mn><mo> </mo><mi mathvariant="normal">J</mi><mo> </mo><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">K</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup><mo> </mo><msup><mi>mol</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></msup></math>]

solution.text:
2Hgg+O2g⟶2HgOs

Heat capacity of calorimeter =20 kJ K-1

Rise in temperature =14.8 K

Heat evolved =20×14.8=296 kJ

ΔH°=ΔU°+ΔngRT

=-296-3×8.3×298×10-3

=-303.42 kJ

ΔH°=2ΔHf°HgOs-2ΔHf°Hgg

-303.42=2ΔHf°HgOs-2×61.32

2ΔHf°HgOs=-180.78 kJ

ΔHf°HgOs=90.39 kJ mol-1
